Judge Damon Keith, who coined the phrase "democracies die behind closed doors", will be remembered for his dedication to upholding the Constitution & his commitment to justice. 

It was an honor to lead this resolution that passed the Senate honoring his life and legacy.

He received more than 40 honorary degrees as well as the Spingarn Medal from the @NAACP, the highest honor awarded by the organization, & the Edward J. Devitt Distinguished Service to Justice Award, the highest award that can be bestowed on a member of the Federal judiciary.

In Garrett v. City of Hamtramck, Judge Keith ruled against housing discrimination & ordered the city to relocate approximately 500 African Americans who had been displaced by federally supported urban renewal projects.
In a 1970 decision, Judge Keith upheld the civil rights of students in Pontiac, Michigan, when he ordered a bus policy and new boundaries for Pontiac schools in order to end racial segregation.

Judge Keith served as one of the first cochairmen of the Michigan Civil Rights Commission at its inception in 1964, where he worked to oppose discrimination and enforce equal protection under the law.

Thread: Judge Damon Keith will forever be remembered as one of the finest public servants the State of Michigan has ever known. 
His commitment to justice, civil rights & the rule of law made a difference in the lives of countless Michiganders & Americans.  https://www.peters.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/senate-passes-peters-stabenow-resolution-honoring-judge-damon-keith¬†‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/EQ07bXElZj
